title: Chapter 5: Probability
text:
NoteRandomness




Random means having no predictable pattern.
Humans are not good at identifying truly random samples or random experiments.
Technology is typically used to simulate randomness.









NoteProbability




Probability is used to measure how often random events occur.
There are two types of probability:

Theoretical probability: Computed using mathematical rules.
Empirical probability: Probabilities from observations/experiments.










NoteTheoretical Probability




How often an event happens if you repeat the experiment over and over.
The relative frequency at which an event occurs after infinitely many repetitions.









NoteEmpirical Probability




Relative frequencies based on experiments or observations of real-life processes.









TipExample 5.1.1. (a) Theoretical or Empirical?




QuestionAnswer


Your friend claims that the probability of getting a 6 when rolling a six-sided die is \(\frac{1}{6}\) because the die is equally likely to land on any of the six sides.


This is a theoretic probability, since the claim was made without performing any experiments.











TipExample 5.1.1. (b) Theoretical or Empirical?




QuestionAnswer


A classmate was trying to figure out the probability of getting three heads when flipping three coins. He flipped three coins ten times, and in one of those ten times, all three coins landed heads up. On the basis of this outcome, he claims that the probability of three heads on one flip is \(\frac{1}{10}\), or 10%.


This is a empirical probability, because the probability was determined from an experiment.











ImportantRemarks.




A theoretical probability is exactly one value.
Empirical probabilities can change with every experiment.









NoteWhy Two Probability Models?




[Theoretical] probabilities may be difficult to compute; however, [empirical] probabilities can help us estimate [theoretical] probabilities.
We cannot always trust a [theoretical] probability model as it may be based on faulty assumptions. [Empirical] probabilities can help us verify or refute an [incorrect theoretical] value.









NoteSimulations



Simulations are [experiments] used to produce [empirical] probabilities.

title: Chapter 5: Probability
text:
Section 5.2. Finding Theoretical Probabilities






NoteGoals




Find the theoretical probabilities of equally likely outcomes.
Find the probability of the outcome of an event.
Use basic probability laws.









NoteEvents




An event is a set of outcome of an experiment to which a probability is assigned.
We use uppercase Latin letters to denote events.
The probability of an event \(A\) is denoted by \(P(A)\).









NoteProperties of Probabilities




The probability of any event \(A\) is always between 0 and 1 (inclusive), i.e., \[
0 \leqslant P(A) \leqslant 1.
\]
The sum of all possible probabilities in an experiment is 1.
An event \(A\) has a probability of 0 if it can never happen.
An event \(A\) has a probability of 1 if it certain to happen.
Probability of any event \(A\) can be expressed as a fraction, decimal, or a percent.









TipExample 5.2.1.




QuestionAnswer


Which of the following cannot be probabilities? Explain your reasoning. \[
110\%, \, 0.75, \, 0.001, \, 5.61, \, -150\%
\]


Any value that is greater than 1 (or 100%) or negative cannot be a probability. Therefore, the valid values are 0.75 and 0.001.











NoteComplement of an Event




The complement of an event \(A\) is the event that \(A\) does not happen.
The complement of \(A\) is denoted by \(A^\complement\).









NoteThe Probability of an Event and its Complement




\(P(A \text{ do not occur}) = 1 - P(A \text{ does occur})\)
Equivalently, \(P(A^\complement) = 1 - P(A)\).









TipExample 5.2.2.




QuestionAnswer


Toss a fair coin. If \(A =\) the event that the coin land on heads, then what is \(A^\complement\)?


\(A^\complement\) is the event that the coin does not land on heads, i.e., the event that the coin land on tails.











TipExample 5.2.3.




QuestionAnswer


Wait for a trolley outside the fort and note its arrival time. If \(A =\) the event the trolley arrives on time, then what is \(A^\complement\)?


\(A^\complement\) is the event that the trolley does not arrive on time.











NoteSample Space and Events for Equally Likely Outcomes




Sample space: The set of all possible equally likely outcomes of an experiment.
Event: Any collection of outcomes in the sample space.









NoteCombining Events with “And”



An event belonging to “\(A\) and \(B\)” must belong to both \(A\) and \(B\).

Combining Events with “Or”
An event belonging to “\(A\) or \(B\)” must belong to either \(A\) or \(B\), or both.









NoteMutually Exclusive Events




Mutually exclusive events: Events in which there are no common outcomes, i.e., events that cannot occur at the same time.
Events that can occur at the same time are not mutually exclusive.









NoteCalculating Probabilities Involving ‘Or’




\(P(A \text{ or } B) =\) \(P(A) + P(B) - P(A \text{ and } B)\)
If \(A\) and \(B\) are mutually exclusive events, then they cannot happen at the same time, i.e., \(P(A \text{ and } B) = 0\).
